awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Algorithms for Environments with Incomplete Information
awd_abstract_narration:
An increasing number of information systems, especially in networking and electronic commerce, require algorithms to make decisions without full knowledge of the optimization problem they are trying to solve.  Challenges of this sort  underlie decision problems in electronic commerce (where relevant information is hidden by parties who may have an incentive to misreport it), online resource allocation (where the quality of decisions in the present depends on  information revealed only in the future), and decentralized networking (where system components try to optimize global objectives armed with only a local view of the network
state).  This research focuses on algorithms which meet  provable guarantees in the face of such uncertainty.

Recent developments in online learning theory and algorithmic mechanism design have opened up the exciting
prospect of designing efficient algorithms with meet  provable worst-case guarantees while still performing nearly as well as existing algorithms in the common case.  The intellectual merit of such algorithms lies in providing an appealing bridge between worst-case and average-case  analysis.  The PI will pursue this prospect in several application domains, including multi-agent learning systems (studying algorithmic notions of trust and reputation based on extending online learning techniques to situations in which multiple learners share information) and auctiondesign (exploring the roles of optimal stopping theory, learning theory, and randomization over outcomes in the design of approximately profit-maximizing auctions). 

This research holds the potential to have a broad impact on technology and society.  For example, improved algorithms for multi-agent online learning could lead to safer and better systems for e-commerce, spam filtering, and sharing  information and content on the Internet.  The PI's education plan further contributes to the project's impact, by developing a new undergraduate course which will make randomness a central notion in the undergraduate computer  science curriculum and by encouraging the participation of graduate students and talented undergraduates in the PI's research.

por.por_cntn:
Algorithms are the procedures by which computers process data and make decisions. The over-arching goal of this project is to gain an improved understanding of how to cope with limitations on an algorithm's ability to access information. Such limitations are becoming commonplace in computing today: an Internet search engine, for example, must solve a problem whose input (a user's information need) is never precisely specified; the uncertainty is compounded by the fact that the content and link structure of the Web are continually changing and that self-interested websites use "link spam" to confuse the ranking system.

One of the primary informational limitations that our work addresses is the inability to look into the future. Perhaps surprisingly, in some settings one can prove that this handicap is surmountable: an algorithm that bases its decisions on observations made in the past and present can perform nearly as well as one gifted with foresight. Online learning and optimal stopping are two research areas that explore different aspects of this phenomenon. The project made key contributions to both areas, providing novel learning and stopping algorithms to solve problems inspired by applications in information retrieval, electronic commerce, and crowdsourcing.

Another type of informational limitation arises when self-interested users have an incentive to conceal or misreport data. Mechanism design is the science of designing systems that ensure their users' rational behavior is consistent with the designer's objectives, a property known as incentive-compatibility. The subject has been studied for more than forty years by economists, three of whom were honored with the 2007 Nobel Prize for founding the field. Over the past fifteen years, computer scientists have infused new ideas into mechanism design in a stream of interdisciplinary work to which this project contributes. An attractive but unattainable vision for CS research in mechanism design would be to provide a computationally efficient procedure for transforming any algorithm whatsoever into an incentive compatible mechanism. While this goal in full generality is known to be impossible, the research supported by this project contributed two quite general positive results identifying cases in which such "black-box reductions" are possible.

Along the way, the research produced other noteworthy discoveries including the solution to a 20-year-old open question concerning the Traveling Salesman Problem and the first rigorous mathematical analysis of a nearly 50-year-old model of housing segregation originally proposed by the economist Thomas Schelling.

The project contributed to the training of eight undergraduate students, four Ph.D. students, and three postdoctoral researchers, all of whom participated in the research. One of the undergraduates participating in the project was recognized as the Male Runner-Up in the 2010 CRA Outstanding Undergraduate Researchers Award. Two of the publications resulting from the project won student paper awards, and another won the Best Paper award at the 2010 ACM Conference on Electronic Commerce.
